New Records: Freddie Freeman's walk-off grand slam in game 1 was the first in the history of World Series play.
Freddie Freeman's home run in game 1 tied the all-time series record for most home runs in five straight World Series games, set by George Springer.
Key Match Events: Freddie Freeman's walk-off grand slam in game 1 decided the game.
Shohei Ohtani suffered a shoulder injury on an attempted steal in game 3.
Alex Verdugo's two-run homer in the bottom of the ninth inning was the first run scored by the Yankees in game 3.
Pre-Game Insights: The game was preceded by a heartwarming dedication to the memory of Fernando Valenzuela, who died just days before the start of the series.
Many baseball experts offered the opinion that Valenzuela’s ‘screwgie,’ baseball’s nickname for the screwball, was comparable to that of the great Carl Hubbell.
Post-Match Reflections: The Dodgers' comeback ability was highlighted after their 3-0 lead over the Yankees.
The Yankees' failure to hit with runners on base was a notable observation.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The game was played in the backdrop of the legacy of Fernando Valenzuela, who helped lead the Dodgers to the World Series against the Yankees in 1981.
Shohei Ohtani played in game 3 despite suffering a shoulder injury.
Others: Walker Buehler threw 5 shutout innings in game 3.
Yoshinobu Yamamoto pitched 6.1 innings and held on for a 4-2 triumph in game 2.
